content: The "Social Security Right To Know Act" requires specific material to be included in the annual report of trustees. Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act is amended to redesignate paragraphs, insert new subparagraphs, and rearrange sentences within the paragraphs. Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act is amended to redesignate paragraphs and rearrange sentences within the paragraphs. This includes changes such as inserting new subparagraphs and striking certain sentences to modify the structure of the document. The amendment to Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act involves redesignating paragraphs, rearranging sentences, inserting new subparagraphs, and modifying the structure of the document. This includes adding specific statements and details regarding the unfunded long-term projected liability of the social security system in terms of inflation-adjusted dollars, present discounted value, and nominal dollars. The condensed text chunk includes details on the financial projections required for reporting under the Social Security Act, such as the amount of deficit or surplus in the last year of the long-term projection period, the economic model and relevant data used for projections, and a summary of key items in inflation-adjusted dollars. Additionally, it explains that Trust Funds balances reflect resources authorized by Congress. Trust Funds balances represent resources authorized by Congress for future social security benefits, but do not consist of real economic assets. These balances are claims against the United States Treasury and must be financed through increased taxes, public borrowing, benefit reduction, or cuts in other Federal expenditures. SEC. 3. MATERIAL TO BE INCLUDED IN SOCIAL SECURITY ACCOUNT STATEMENT. Section 1143(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a comparison of annual social security tax inflows to benefits paid annually, determined by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration. The curr_chunk discusses the cash flow deficit in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund, the percentage of benefits that could be paid from social security tax inflows, an explanation required by section 201(c)(2)(G), and the average rate of return on old-age insurance benefits compared to social security taxes. The curr_chunk discusses the total amount of social security taxes a taxpayer expects to pay, including the inflation-adjusted average rate of return for workers born in every year beginning with 1900, presented in chart or graph form with an explanatory caption by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration. SEC. 4. USE OF CONTINUOUS WORK HISTORY SAMPLE FOR STATISTICAL RESEARCH. The Social Security Administration will provide the Continuous Work History Sample (CWHS) data for statistical research purposes, with limitations on data release to ensure individual privacy. The Continuous Work History Sample (CWHS) data from the Social Security Administration is provided for statistical research purposes, with privacy protections in place. Personally Identifiable Information is removed before data release, and users must reimburse the Office of Research and Statistics for data costs. Definitions for CWHS and users are provided in this section.
